Documentation.name: DAF Solution Architecture
Documentation.notes: Seven mandatory views for DAF Solution Architecture

Stereotype.name: Application Use-Case
Stereotype.notes: An Application Use-Case diagram displays the relationships between consumers and providers of application services. Application services are consumed by actors or other application ser vices and the Application Use-Case diagram provides added richness in describing application functionality by illustrating how and when that functionality is used. The purpose of the Application Use-Case diagram is to help to describe and validate the interaction between actors and their roles with applications. As the architecture progresses, the use-case can evolve from functional information to include technical realization detail. Application use-cases can also be re-used in more detailed systems design work.

Stereotype.name: Domain
Stereotype.notes: The Domain Model provides the business vocabulary - terms and facts of the enterprise. It uses the vocabulary of the domain, thus allowing a representation of the model to be communicated to non-technical stakeholders. It should not refer to any technical implementations such as databases or software components that are being designed. This is also often called Canonical Model. It consist in extended UML classes with properties, their relationships (Associations, Aggregations, Compositions and Generalizations) .

Stereotype.name: Deployment Diagram
Stereotype.notes: A deployment diagram in the Unified Modeling Language models the physical deployment of artifacts on nodes. It is composed by Nodes, application components and execution environments. In DAF it contains all the concept to describe a complete deployment of a application

Stereotype.name: Solution Concept
Stereotype.notes: A solution concept diagram provides a high-level orientation of the solution that is envisaged in order to meet the objectives of the architecture engagement. In contrast to the more formal and detailed architecture diagrams developed in the following phases, the solution concept represents a pencil sketch of the element involved in the expected solution at the outset of the engagement. This diagram may embody key objectives, requirements and constraints for the engagement, and also highlight work areas to be investigated in more detail with formal architecture modeling. The purpose of this diagram is to quickly on-board and align stakeholders for a particular change initiative, so that all participants understand what the architecture engagement is seeking to achieve and how it is expected that a particular solution approach will meet the needs of the enterprise.

Stereotype.name: Enterprise Context
Stereotype.notes: The Enterprise Context Diagram is a Business Architecture artifact that provides a single view of the key stakeholders and processes involved in the business. It also establishes a framework to further breakdown and understand the business.

Stereotype.name: Component
Stereotype.notes: A component diagram depicts how components are wired together to form larger components or software systems. They are used to illustrate the structure of arbitrarily complex systems.

Stereotype.name: Road Map
Stereotype.notes: The road map contains elements placed in a time line, with a dynamic legend supporting the different phases of the element over time.

Stereotype.name: Entity Model
Stereotype.notes: describes interrelated things of interest in a specific domain of knowledge. A basic ER model is composed of entity types (which classify the things of interest) and specifies relationships that can exist between entities (instances of those entity types).

Stereotype.name: API
Stereotype.notes:
a diagram to model API endpoints and JSON schema classes. it represents how different components of a system communicate and the data structures exchanged between them.
  • API Endpoints: Each class represents an endpoint (e.g., /users, /orders/{id}) and includes details like HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) and a brief description of its purpose.
JSON Schema Classes: Represent data models exchanged in API requests and responses.
